verses.text: This is the word of the LORD that came to Jeremiah the prophet about the Philistines, before Pharaoh attacked Gaza:
verses.comment: This introduction establishes both the timing and the audience of this prophecy. The Philistines were long-time enemies of Israel, and God speaks through His prophet Jeremiah before a devastating attack. Cross-references show a consistent biblical message that God is sovereign over the nations (see Isaiah 14:29-31).

verses.text: The LORD says: Look, waters are rising from the north, becoming an overflowing torrent, flooding the land and all that is in it, the city and its people. Everyone in the land will cry out, and all who live there will wail.
verses.comment: The imagery of rising waters as judgment is found elsewhere in the prophets. Water here symbolizes overwhelming armies, likely those of Babylon. This broad devastation alludes to the all-encompassing effects of divine justice, a theme extended in the New Testament to the final judgment (cf. Matt. 24:39).

verses.text: At the noise of the stomping hooves of his strong horses, at the rushing of his chariots, the rumble of his wheels, fathers do not turn back for their children, their hands go limp,
verses.comment: The terror described is total—so great that fathers abandon even their own children. The horror of war and judgment evokes spiritual realities: sin separates families and communities from one another and from God, echoing the necessity of divine grace and a mediating priesthood for reconciliation.

verses.text: Because the day has come to destroy all the Philistines, to cut off from Tyre and Sidon every ally that remains. For the LORD is destroying the Philistines, the remnant from the coastland of Caphtor.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty over Gentile nations is a recurring biblical theme. The reference to Caphtor ties back to the Philistines’ origins. The destruction of allies foreshadows God's plan to bring all nations ultimately to the knowledge of Him through an everlasting covenant—a reality fulfilled in the new covenant through Christ, in which there is no distinction between Jew and Gentile (Rom. 10:12).

verses.text: Baldness has come upon Gaza, Ashkelon is silenced. The remnant of their valley—how long will you gash yourselves?
verses.comment: Shaving the head and self-mutilation were practices of mourning among the Philistines and other ancient peoples. However, God’s people were prohibited from these practices (cf. Lev. 19:28). The contrast underscores the unique holiness required of God’s people—a foreshadowing of Christ’s call for spiritual worship and transformation, not outward ritual.

verses.text: Ah, sword of the LORD, how long until you are quiet? Put yourself back into your scabbard; rest and be still!
verses.comment: This verse personifies the sword of the LORD, representing His judgment. The plea for mercy echoes throughout salvation history, culminating in the prayer for peace offered by Christ (see Luke 23:34). There is both a cry for justice and for ultimate reconciliation, themes tied closely to the sacrificial mediation later fully revealed in the New Testament.

verses.text: But how can it be quiet, when the LORD has commanded it? Against Ashkelon and the sea coast, there He has appointed it.
verses.comment: The inevitability of God’s purposes is emphasized. The sword cannot rest when God has appointed judgment. Spiritually, this points to the certainty of divine justice and the assurance that God’s decrees come to pass—an idea echoed in the perpetual mission of the Church to carry out God's will until His purposes are accomplished (Matt. 16:18).
